title: Outdated and End-of-Life Software Components
description:
The application is running on outdated and end-of-life (EOL) software components that are no longer receiving security updates. Specifically:

- Python 2.7.18 (EOL since January 1, 2020)
- Werkzeug 1.0.1 (released in 2020, several versions behind current)

These versions have known security vulnerabilities and are no longer supported by their maintainers. Python 2.7 reached end-of-life over 5 years ago and contains numerous unpatched security vulnerabilities. Werkzeug 1.0.1 has known CVEs including CVE-2023-25577 (host header injection) and CVE-2023-23934 (cookie parsing vulnerabilities).
impact:
Use of EOL software exposes the application to:
- Known security vulnerabilities that will never be patched
- Potential remote code execution through Python 2.7 vulnerabilities
- Host header injection attacks (CVE-2023-25577)
- Cookie parsing vulnerabilities (CVE-2023-23934)
- Lack of security features present in modern versions
- Compliance violations (PCI-DSS, HIPAA, etc. require supported software)
- Increased attack surface as exploits for these versions are publicly available
evidence:
Server header reveals outdated components across multiple endpoints:

POC Execution Results:
- Endpoint /: Server: Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/2.7.18
- Endpoint /xss20: Server: Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/2.7.18
- OPTIONS /xss20: Server: Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/2.7.18

The POC successfully detected:
[!] CRITICAL: Python 2.7 detected (EOL since January 1, 2020)
    Python 2.7 is end-of-life and no longer receives security updates
[!] HIGH: Werkzeug 1.0.x detected (outdated, has known CVEs)
    Known vulnerabilities:
    - CVE-2023-25577: Host Header Injection
    - CVE-2023-23934: Cookie Parsing Vulnerability

Original detection command:
curl -v http://localhost:5001/xss20 2>&1 | grep Server
Response: Server: Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/2.7.18

Python 2.7 reached EOL on January 1, 2020
Werkzeug 1.0.1 is from March 2020, current stable version is 3.x
remediation:
1. Immediately upgrade to Python 3.11+ (latest stable version)
2. Upgrade Werkzeug to version 3.x or latest stable
3. Update all other dependencies to currently supported versions
4. Implement automated dependency scanning in CI/CD pipeline (e.g., Dependabot, Snyk, OWASP Dependency-Check)
5. Establish policy for regular security updates and dependency reviews
6. Consider suppressing version information in Server header to prevent information disclosure (add 'SERVER_SOFTWARE' configuration)
7. Review and update all deprecated Python 2.7 code syntax for Python 3 compatibility
8. Test thoroughly after migration to ensure application functionality is maintained
